https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.11/5348/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

Two questions: 

1. It seems that the stdout from all tests in a class is output together on jenkins?
2. your observation does seem like a problem, but it is hard to see how that bug could cause the invalid state transition in the context of this particular test. Still, it's worth fixing.

>  We should be holding a lock when we call isEmpty(). If this call had returned true incorrectly, then we would have proceeded to send the COMMIT and only afterwards would the batches be sent.

The incomplete set is batches which have been sent, but which have not been acknowledged. So it seems that a fallout of a race on 'isEmpty' would be that we do another poll waiting for the flush to complete. 

Also, in the test failure, we were transitioning to `ABORTABLE_ERROR` because the batches expired when sitting in the queue. So they somehow were not sent but yet the commit completed. I don't see think this race condition could result in that. 

Of course, we should fix this, but we also need to keep looking for the root cause IMO.
Hmm. it seems that the logs on jenkins still don't have trace level for the transaction manager, even though they do when I run it locally. Very puzzling :(

I thought about it and it does seem possible. Here is the sequence of events:

1. The two records are queued to be sent.
2. The `commitTransaction()` API is invoked.
3. At this point, we check whether there are unflushed batches. Because of the bug, we incorrectly return false.
4. We send EndTxn and await completion. After completion, we transition to READY.
5. The records are still queued, but they won't be sent because `isSendToPartitionAllowed` will return false (there is no ongoing transaction).
6. Eventually, the records expire in the queue. This does not trigger retry; we just fail the batch with `TimeoutException`, which causes a transition to ABORTABLE_ERROR

Since the records were never sent, the read_uncommitted consumer of course will time out waiting for them. 

Anyway, I agree we shouldn't close this out until we have more evidence.

So which `isEmpty` are you referring to. From https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/3348 it seems that you are referring to synchronization on `this.incomplete.incomplete.isEmpty`. That set is only those batches which have already been drained from the queue and sent, but for which we are awaiting a response.

Yes, as mentioned offline, the access to the dequeue in `hasUnflushedBatches` is also missing synchronization. It is far-fetched, but not impossible that they both return incorrectly. Since we have no other theories to go on at the moment, we will probably have to get more logging and see if we can reproduce the problem with both issues fixed.
By the way, can we resurface this discussion?
Seems like we need to update the PR description as @hachikuji has added one additional fix. This seems important enough to wait for it to be merged before doing RC1.

@ewencp there's a reasonably easy solution to do something like that: run an additional gradle target with a single test (say `PlaintextConsumerTest`) specifying a different log4j.properties file. I'm still not sure if it's worth doing that compared to what we have in this PR. If people want fast tests, they should be running the unit tests anyway.

@guozhangwang @mjsax ok, I got it! I thought `WindowedSerde` is just an abbreviation for the concept.
Will refactor this.

@hachikuji Thanks for the patch. LGTM. 

One thing not directly related to the patch. It seems that when we delete the old segments, we don't change ProducerIdEntry.currentTxnFirstOffset. This means that ProducerIdEntry.currentTxnFirstOffset may no long be in the log. Not sure if this matters, but it probably means that ProducerIdEntry.currentTxnFirstOffset may be recovered inconsistently depending on whether the snapshot exists or not.

So I've been procrastinating on this patch this evening and I think it's because I'm not too satisfied with the solution. I've been thinking of an alternative. The current problem is that we sort of stupidly assume that no snapshot implies upgrade and we're now trying to clear several hurdles to make that assumption work. Perhaps we can just strengthen the upgrade check. In addition to having no snapshot file, maybe we can look at the message format version of the last batch appended to the log. If the version is old, we can skip rebuilding the producer state. This of course depends on the assumption that users won't downgrade the message format version, but we assume that in the fetch handler anyway, so it seems fine. Thoughts?
